                                 I N  A S S E M B L Y

       Introduced by M. of A. ROSENTHAL -- Multi-Sponsored by -- M. of A. HOOP-
         ER -- read once and referred to the Committee on Education

       AN  ACT  to  amend  the education law, in relation to training of school
         athletic coaches in the recognition and management of head injuries

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Legislative intent. Concussions are one of the most common-
    2  ly  reported  injuries  in  children  and adolescents who participate in
    3  sports and recreational activities.  The centers for disease control and
    4  prevention estimates that as many as three million nine hundred thousand
    5  sports-related and recreation-related concussions occur  in  the  United
    6  States each year.
    7    A  concussion  is  a  type of brain injury that can range from mild to
    8  severe and can disrupt the way the brain normally works. It is caused by
    9  a blow or motion to the head or body  that  causes  the  brain  to  move
   10  rapidly  inside the skull. The risk of catastrophic injuries or death is
   11  significant when a concussion or head injury is not  properly  evaluated
   12  and managed.
   13    Concussions  can occur in any organized or unorganized sport or recre-
   14  ational activity and can result from a fall or  from  players  colliding
   15  with  each  other, the ground, or with obstacles. Concussions occur with
   16  or without loss of consciousness, but the vast majority  occurs  without
   17  loss of consciousness.
   18    Continuing to play with a concussion or symptoms of head injury leaves
   19  the  young  athlete  especially  vulnerable  to  greater injury and even
   20  death.  Despite some increased recognition about the importance of diag-
   21  nosing and treating concussions, some affected youth athletes are prema-
   22  turely returned to play, which can have  harmful  and  potentially  even
   23  deadly  results.    It  is  therefore imperative that adults supervising
   24  young athletes in school settings receive proper training  to  recognize
   25  and  evaluate  concussions and other traumatic sport-related injuries in

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD01468-01-1

       A. 1480                             2

    1  order to ensure the safety of New York's children who compete in school-
    2  related sports activities.
    3    S  2.  The  education law is amended by adding a new section 3001-e to
    4  read as follows:
    5    S 3001-E. HEAD INJURY RECOGNITION TRAINING FOR COACHES OF  EXTRA-CLASS
    6  PUBLIC  SCHOOL  ATHLETIC ACTIVITIES AND COACHES OF EXTRA-CLASS NONPUBLIC
    7  SCHOOL ATHLETIC ACTIVITIES. 1. (A) COACHES OF EXTRA-CLASS PUBLIC  SCHOOL
    8  ATHLETIC ACTIVITIES AND COACHES OF EXTRA-CLASS NONPUBLIC SCHOOL ATHLETIC
    9  ACTIVITIES SHALL RECEIVE TRAINING TO LEARN HOW TO RECOGNIZE THE SYMPTOMS
   10  OF  A  CONCUSSION  AND HOW TO SEEK PROPER MEDICAL TREATMENT FOR A PERSON
   11  SUSPECTED OF HAVING A CONCUSSION.
   12    (B) THE COMMISSIONER SHALL ESTABLISH BY  REGULATION,  IN  CONSULTATION
   13  WITH  A  REPRESENTATIVE FROM THE GOVERNING AUTHORITY FOR INTERSCHOLASTIC
   14  ACTIVITIES, A REPRESENTATIVE FROM THE  STATE  ORGANIZATION  REPRESENTING
   15  LICENSED  ATHLETIC  TRAINERS,  A  REPRESENTATIVE  FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF
   16  HEALTH KNOWLEDGEABLE IN THE SUBJECT MATTER  OF  CONCUSSIONS,  AND  OTHER
   17  INTERESTED  PARTIES  KNOWLEDGEABLE IN THE SUBJECT MATTER OF CONCUSSIONS,
   18  THE FOLLOWING PROVISIONS:
   19    (I) THE MINIMUM STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS OF THE  TRAINING  DESCRIBED
   20  IN  THIS  SECTION, INCLUDING A LIST OF APPROVED PROVIDERS OF SUCH TRAIN-
   21  ING; AND
   22    (II) TIMELINES AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT, TO THE EXTENT  PRACTICA-
   23  BLE, EVERY COACH RECEIVES THE TRAINING DESCRIBED IN THIS SECTION; AND
   24    (III) QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED OF LICENSED HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS TO
   25  BE PERMITTED TO PROVIDE MEDICAL RELEASES AS OUTLINED IN PARAGRAPH (B) OF
   26  SUBDIVISION TWO OF THIS SECTION.
   27    (C) IMPLEMENTATION OF REGULATIONS ENACTED PURSUANT TO THIS SUBDIVISION
   28  SHALL NOT BE MADE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE EMPLOYING SCHOOL DISTRICT OR
   29  NONPUBLIC  SCHOOL  UNLESS STATE FUNDING OR REIMBURSEMENT IS PROVIDED FOR
   30  ASSOCIATED COSTS.
   31    2. (A) A COACH MAY NOT ALLOW A MEMBER OF A  SCHOOL  ATHLETIC  TEAM  TO
   32  PARTICIPATE  IN  ANY ATHLETIC EVENT OR TRAINING ON THE SAME DAY THAT THE
   33  MEMBER:
   34    (I) EXHIBITS SIGNS, SYMPTOMS OR BEHAVIORS CONSISTENT WITH A CONCUSSION
   35  FOLLOWING AN OBSERVED OR SUSPECTED INJURY TO THE HEAD OR BODY; OR
   36    (II) HAS BEEN DIAGNOSED WITH A CONCUSSION.
   37    (B) A COACH MAY ALLOW A MEMBER  OF  A  SCHOOL  ATHLETIC  TEAM  WHO  IS
   38  PROHIBITED  FROM  PARTICIPATING  IN  AN  ATHLETIC  EVENT OR TRAINING, AS
   39  DESCRIBED IN PARAGRAPH (A) OF THIS SUBDIVISION,  TO  PARTICIPATE  IN  AN
   40  ATHLETIC EVENT OR TRAINING NO SOONER THAN THE DAY AFTER THE MEMBER EXPE-
   41  RIENCED AN INJURY TO THE HEAD OR BODY AND ONLY AFTER THE MEMBER RECEIVES
   42  A  MEDICAL  RELEASE FROM A LICENSED HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL WITH QUALI-
   43  FICATIONS AS DEFINED PURSUANT TO SUBPARAGRAPH (III) OF PARAGRAPH (B)  OF
   44  SUBDIVISION ONE OF THIS SECTION.
   45    S  3.  This  act shall take effect July 1, 2013 and shall apply to all
   46  school years commencing on or after such date; provided  that  effective
   47  immediately, the commissioner of education is authorized and directed to
   48  promulgate  all  rules and regulations and take all actions necessary to
   49  implement the provisions of this act on or before its effective date.
